bibl.title: Report on Mr. Caruba, by Henry R. Muller, [1923]

div1.p: In this pathology report Muller describes the liver and kidney from a patient, and states that the case was probably not yellow fever.

div1.head: Report on Mr. Caruba, by Henry R. Muller, [1923]
div1.p:
Very extensive necrosis; no lobules preserved intact. Here and
there are a few preserved liver cords and cells. Marked diffuse infiltration
of necrotic tissue with lymphocytes and plasma cells. Portal connective tissue
also necrotic.

Fine fat granules in preserved liver cells (not all) and scattered
in necrotic tissue.

Several foreign-body giant cells present, containing many nuclei and
elongated, oat-shaped, hyaline bodies. These are surrounded with fibroblasts
and round cells.

Capsules of glomeruli slightly thickened. Glomeruli moderately
infiltrated with “round-cells”.

Many tubules contain greenish yellow material, and their epi-
thelial cells are stained the same color. This resembles altered blood.
Tubular epithelium only moderately swollen; slight amount of pink-staining
material in lumen of tubules.
No fatty degeneration of kidney epithelium.

list.head: DIAGNOSIS:
list.item: 1. Diffuse necrosis of liver, with chronic hepatitis.

div1.p:
OPINION: Probably not yellow fever. May be acute yellow atrophy, or atrophy of
liver sometimes seen in salvarsan (or other drugs) administration.
